outboundReferences.contextLine: We start with the classical equations for angular momentum and energy, from [[gordy-cook]]
with angular velocity $\omega$ and moment of inertia tensor $\bf{I}$; for a molecule in $xyz$ coordinates with atom masses $m$, the matrix elements are (taken again from [[gordy-cook]]):
- Transitions with $\Delta K \neq 0$ are not observed for rigid rotors; you need [[centrifugal-distortion]]

inboundReferences.contextLine: Building on top of the [[rigid-rotor]] approximation, we get a more "realistic" picture of a rotating object by including centrifugal distortion: the shape of an object changes with more and more rotation, thereby affecting the spacing between energy levels.
[[rigid-rotor]]s, followed by perturbative effects such as [[centrifugal-distortion]], [[hyperfine-splitting]], magnetic fields, etc.
